ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge about the meeting point between hardware and software, various hardware components on a chip and their performances, what various specs mean when I see them listed on a computers product page, etc.
Computer micro architecture (the fundamentals of modern stuff at least) and various low-level compiler optimizations. Also learned quite a bit about the LLVM compiler.
I learned a great deal during this class. I was very impressed with the depth of knowledge about architecture that I learned.
An in-depth exploration of computer architecture and microarchitecture, and an overview of some fundamental compiler optimization tools and techniques (specifically in LLVM).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Abhishek is the best and most engaging CS lecturer Ive ever encountered at Yale. You can feel that he genuinely cares about the class, the students, and the material. The lectures proceed in extremely intuitive ways, and I would recommend taking any class with him. I had absolutely no interest in hardware before this class, and now Im like, its pretty interesting!! Also, I actually got feedback on my code that was submitted for homework, which has never happened to me at Yale before (and Im a senior). The TA actually read through my code and gave me specific comments on what couldve been improved. Weaknesses- the concepts taught in class were not super well translated to the homework (LLVM programming), because there was so many auxiliary components in LLVMs implementation of algorithms taught in class.
The workload of the course didnt hit for a few weeks which made it a bit hard to plan for during shopping period. The assignments were also occasionally a bit hard to follow

I really liked the programming intensive assignments. I appreciated how much we got to get our hands dirty so to speak. While they were not my favorite, the written assignments did help to solidify the concepts in my head

The computer architecture material was taught very well, and I haven't seen any other classes in the department that cover this material in anywhere near the same level of detail. Despite the depth and breadth of the content covered in half a semester, all of the lectures felt very accessible to a CS student with no prior background in computer arch or EE. It would have been nice to have some more hands-on assignments to work with some of this material, but I understand that next year's iteration of the course will include more of these assignments. The compiler content was also interesting, but it felt very secondary to the architecture ideas. We only had time to cover a handful of ideas in compiler optimization, and it felt like the pace of the course slowed down considerably in the second half of the semester. The compiler assignments were challenging and offered a good hands-on introduction to working in LLVM.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Abhishek is a gem and his attitude alone can move mountains. This area of CS is also rather neglected in our department, since we dont emphasize an EE or computer engineering component to the CS major.
Absolutely. Id recommend this course to any student with an interest in low-level computing
Yes, if you are interested in the way compilers and architecture works in modern computers, take this course.

Absolutely yes. I found the architecture material to be very interesting, and one of a few areas within CS that is relatively challenging to self-study because of how dominated it is by industry. The assignments familiarize you with the LLVM codebase and are generally well organized. That said, take note that future iterations of the course will likely be much higher workload than the class offering this year, so expect the workload rating of the course to go up considerably.
